data.title: Wake up !
data.solution:
import numpy as p
I=input
t,u=[int(i)for i in I().split(':')]
n=int(I())
s=[]
for i in range(n):s.append(int(I()))
l=p.lcm.reduce(s)
x=t+l//60+(u+l%60)//60
print("{:02d}:{:02d}".format(x%24,(u+l)%60),end='')
if x>23:print("+"+str(x//24))
data.statement:
Waking up in the morning is the hardest thing that happens to you during the day. Opening an eye, then a second, then move a toe, ... until you are finally up always takes ages. When you do not fall asleep again during the process !

Over time, you have developed a strong strategy : you use several clocks that ring all together. But since you cannot wake up at the first ring, you have the bad habit of snoozing them all. You finally get up when they all ring together for the second time. But since they have all different built-in snooze time, anticipating your real get up time is not always easy.

For instance, it you have two clocks with 10 and 15 min as their respective snooze time and you set them for 7am, you will finally get up at 7:30 when they ring at the same time again.
data.constraints:
0<[[n]]<30 (yeah, waking up is THAT hard !)
0<[[snooze]]<30
Time is always in 24-hour format, ie. between 00:00 and 23:59
data.stubGenerator:
read time:string(5)
read n:int
loop n read snooze:int
write time
data.inputDescription:
[[time]] : the time of the first ring in hh:mm format
[[n]] : the number of clocks you use
On the next [[n]] lines : [[snooze]] time in minutes
data.outputDescription:
time : the final get up time in hh:mm format. If it takes you several days to wake up, add the number of days with the following syntax : hh:mm+d
You count a day each time passes midnight.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Waking up in the morning is the hardest thing that happens to you during the day. Opening an eye, then a second, then move a toe, ... until you are finally up always takes ages. When you do not fall asleep again during the process !

Over time, you have developed a strong strategy : you use several clocks that ring all together. But since you cannot wake up at the first ring, you have the bad habit of snoozing them all. You finally get up when they all ring together for the second time. But since they have all different built-in snooze time, anticipating your real get up time is not always easy.

For instance, it you have two clocks with 10 and 15 min as their respective snooze time and you set them for 7am, you will finally get up at 7:30 when they ring at the same time again.
Input
time : the time of the first ring in hh:mm format
n : the number of clocks you use
On the next n lines : snooze time in minutes
Output
time : the final get up time in hh:mm format. If it takes you several days to wake up, add the number of days with the following syntax : hh:mm+d
You count a day each time passes midnight.
Constraints
0<n<30 (yeah, waking up is THAT hard !)
0<snooze<30
Time is always in 24-hour format, ie. between 00:00 and 23:59
Example
Input
07:00
2
10
15
Output
07:30
